instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
[B][FONT=arial]Hope you can help. I have a 2015 MacBook air with the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board. The issue I'm having is the battery will not charge. Computer runs fine on wall adapter and the computer sees the battery. I tried another battery with the same result. I'm a bit new at this but catch on fast. I already have the board view for this board and have started troubleshooting.[/FONT][/B]

[B]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.4v so I assume <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> is the issue. Is there a way for me to test <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>? Anything else I should be checking?

Additionally I am using coconutBattery to see the Charging info. When I first attach the charger it shows charging at 10 watts then gradually drops to 0 watts.

Any help would be great.

Thanks[/B]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message: Also on board diagnostic shows no issues.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Any history available?
Post voltage for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, pins 9, 15, 26.
Measure onboard exact value (ohm scale) for <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86.
Do you get amber light when charger is connected?
Do you have original Apple 60/85W charger, MagSafe 2 model?

OSX shows some message like Replace/Service now for battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> as well?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
As far as history goes not much other than being informed of the charging issue. Board looks clean. Water indicators all white.

On <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> it appears there may be some corrosion between pins 8 and 9. Anyways here are the read outs. 

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Pin 9 - .03v
Pin 15 - 8.56v
Pin 26 - 14.59v

7180 - 100.3k
7181 - 62.2k

7185 - .466
7186 - .331

Amber light shows on charger even with battery unplugged

45 mag safe 2 oem charger being used

No messages. Battery shows good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
"Amber light shows on charger even with battery unplugged"
Normal behaviour. MagSafe light will switch back to green only if battery is 100% charged.

Try another charger, 60/85W if possible.

"Pin 26 - 14.59v"
Should be 0V in normal mode.

"Pin 15 - 8.56v"
Really???
Check again that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message: Well I guess I am going to try reflowing the chip. After cleaning it good with alcohol I am now successfully charging the battery BUT only charging at 1.84 watts. I assume there is additional corrosion that I cannot see.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Give time to fully charge it and take a look to the time reported.
Post again pin 9 & 15 voltage.

Please, do NOT quote an entire post from few cm above; is not aesthetic...

It took approximately 36 hours to charge from 15% to 100%

Pin 9       .10v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Chane <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and check its traces.
Post voltage for pin 1/<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>.
Also check <RESISTOR>R7113</RESISTOR> and its traces/solders.

threads.message:
I double checked. This thing seems to act differently Everytime power is applied as far as <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> goes

Pin 9 -   3.4v
Pin 15 - .07v


<CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> looks good

<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 is 1.58v

<RESISTOR>R7113</RESISTOR> looks good

threads.message: Noob moment. Should I have the battery attached to the board for these tests?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Yes, both charger and battery connected.

"Pin 9 - 3.4v"
Are you really sure?
That is overcurrent on charger side.
Double check <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 and theyr traces to <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
With battery connected

<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> pin 1  7.9v


<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Pin 9   2.15v
Pin 15  .23v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
"With battery connected"
Should I suppose charger is connected too?

"Pin 9 2.15v"
Still too high.
As per schematic, 1.4V means more than 8A; imagine 2V how much is...
So
"Double check <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22..."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Yes that was with charger and battery connected

Check this out. Right below pin 9. 

Trace contacts look rough. Anything I can do to clean this up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Here is <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22

Any resistance values I should be checking for?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Pin 9 looks good, as <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 too.
But components and traces for pins 7/8 are pretty ugly.
Clean that area and check/replace <RESISTOR>R7115</RESISTOR>/16 and <CAPACITOR>C7115</CAPACITOR>/16.
Aso take a look to R/<CAPACITOR>C7142</CAPACITOR>.
All these are involved in charging process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message: Pretty sure I found issue. The Trace between <RESISTOR>R7115</RESISTOR>/16 to <CAPACITOR>C7116</CAPACITOR> is not making a connection. Should I try laying in a wire jumper?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message:
Follow schematic and rebuild the traces correctly.
Test points get corroded usually.
Be sure to have good solders on the components pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charging Issue
threads.message: Forgot to update this. Came down to rebuilding some traces. Thanks again everyone
